* is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless").

|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |                                                                                |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | [monst.c#line1299](/wiki/Monst.c#line1299 "Monst.c")                           |

A **brown mold**, F, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The brown mold is a type of [mold](/wiki/Mold "Mold") that has an affinity to [cold](/wiki/Cold "Cold"), and like all molds it is [sessile](/wiki/Sessile "Sessile") and lacks limbs, eyes or a head.

A brown mold has a [passive attack](/wiki/Passive_attack "Passive attack") that can trigger when it is attacked in melee and not killed, dealing cold damage against attackers without [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance") dependent on their level. This passive attack increases the mold's HP by half the damage inflicted[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) - if enough HP is gained from this, the mold will undergo [division](/wiki/Division "Division"), halving its HP (rounded up) and creating a second mold with almost the same amount of HP.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) Brown molds possess [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and cold resistance.

[Eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") a brown mold [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 3% chance each of granting poison resistance or cold resistance.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [4.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [4.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [4.4 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [4.5 notdNetHack](#notdNetHack)
  - [4.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [4.7 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [4.8 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated brown molds are always created hostile.

## Strategy

Brown molds are not threatening to a [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") that has cold resistance, and even heroes without the property can avoid [YASD](/wiki/YASD "YASD") against one by remaining attentive. Any form of [ranged attack](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") can dispose of a brown mold easily; while [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") are also capable of handling them, some early pets may have trouble dealing enough damage to outpace the mold's HP gain and passive damage.

Brown molds can provide an early source of cold resistance and poison resistance for a hero, in spite of the low odds.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a brown mold can be useful for giving resistances to a pet [pony](/wiki/Pony "Pony") (e.g. as a [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")).

## History

The brown mold first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), brown molds have a 9⁄10 chance of [reviving](/wiki/Reviving "Reviving") from their corpses like other non-[lichen](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen") fungi and molds.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) A brown mold has an overall 7.4% chance of generating from a corpse that reaches 51 turns of age, is not [acidic](/wiki/Acidic "Acidic"), and is not located within or on top of a square of [water](/wiki/Water "Water"), [ice](/wiki/Ice "Ice") or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava").[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

Brown molds can be generated in [fungus farms](/wiki/Fungus_farm "Fungus farm").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), brown molds have a roughly 1% chance to grow from old corpses similar to SLASH'EM, and can revive from their own corpses.

Brown mold corpses can only be eaten safely by a hero or monster with cold resistance, and will otherwise deal 2d12 damage when bitten into - their tins are still safe to consume.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper") items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses, though with much lower odds.

Brown mold corpses can be used to brew [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion") by [dipping](/wiki/Dipping "Dipping") them in [fruit juice](/wiki/Fruit_juice "Fruit juice"), which eventually turns the juice into a [potion of sleeping](/wiki/Potion_of_sleeping "Potion of sleeping").

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. A brown mold can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a [brown moldier](/wiki/Brown_moldier "Brown moldier"), though this does not normally occur in gameplay.

Attempting to [cook](/wiki/Cook "Cook") a brown mold corpse at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace") will cause it to immediately revive.

### notdNetHack

In [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), in addition to dNetHack details, brown molds can often be encountered in the [Ice Caves](/index.php?title=Ice_Caves\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Ice Caves (page does not exist)") [adventure branch](/index.php?title=Adventure_branch\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Adventure branch (page does not exist)").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), tame monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a brown mold can be useful for giving resistances to a pet [pony](/wiki/Pony "Pony") or other [herbivore](/wiki/Herbivore "Herbivore").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), red molds are slightly less likely to generate from old corpses due to the addition of some new fungi and molds. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. As in SpliceHack, a brown mold can grow up into a brown moldier, though this does not normally occur in gameplay.

Similar to xNetHack, brown mold corpses can be used to brew potions by dipping them in fruit juice - in Hack'EM, this eventually turns the juice into a [potion of blood](/index.php?title=Potion_of_blood_\(SLASH%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Potion of blood (SLASH'EM) (page does not exist)").

Monsters eating corpses functions as in EvilHack, allowing the hero to feed brown mold corpses to applicable pets so they can potentially gain intrinsics.

## Encyclopedia entry

Mold, multicellular organism of the division Fungi, typified  
by plant bodies composed of a network of cottony filaments.  
The colors of molds are due to spores borne on the filaments.  
Most molds are saprophytes. Some species (e.g., penicillium)  
are used in making cheese and antibiotics.

\[ The Concise Columbia Encyclopedia ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2917](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L2917): *case for cold passive against you*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2927](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L2927): *cold passive healing against you*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1671](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1671): *case for cold passive against monsters*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1682](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1682): *cold passive healing against monsters*
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2933](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L2933): *case against you calls `split_mon` function in [potion.c](/wiki/Potion.c "Potion.c")*
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1685](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1685): *case against monsters also calls `split_mon` function in [potion.c](/wiki/Potion.c "Potion.c")*
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/potion.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2379](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/potion.c#L2379)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [mkobj.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 764](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c#line764 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c")
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [mkobj.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 765](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c#line765 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c")
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [do.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1685](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/do.c#line1685 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/do.c")
11. [↑](#cite_ref-11) [mkobj.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 811](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c#line811 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c")
12. [↑](#cite_ref-12) [do.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1680](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/do.c#line1680 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/do.c")

Brown mold

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
F brown mold
Difficulty 2
Attacks Passive 0d6 cold
F brown mold
Difficulty 2
Attacks

Passive 0d6 cold

Base level 1
Base experience 9
Speed 0
Base AC 9
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 50
Nutritional value 30
Size Small
Resistances Cold, poison
Resistances conveyed Cold (3%), poison (3%)

A brown mold:

  • does not breathe.
  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
Reference monst.c#line1299

A brown mold, F, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The brown mold is a type of mold that has an affinity to cold, and like all molds it is sessile and lacks limbs, eyes or a head.

A brown mold has a passive attack that can trigger when it is attacked in melee and not killed, dealing cold damage against attackers without cold resistance dependent on their level. This passive attack increases the mold's HP by half the damage inflicted[1][2][3][4] - if enough HP is gained from this, the mold will undergo division, halving its HP (rounded up) and creating a second mold with almost the same amount of HP.[5][6][7] Brown molds possess poison resistance and cold resistance.

Eating a brown mold corpse or tin has a 3% chance each of granting poison resistance or cold resistance.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History

    • 4.1 SLASH'EM

    • 4.5 notdNetHack
    • 4.6 EvilHack
    • 4.7 SlashTHEM
    • 4.8 Hack'EM
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Randomly generated brown molds are always created hostile.

Strategy

Brown molds are not threatening to a hero that has cold resistance, and even heroes without the property can avoid YASD against one by remaining attentive. Any form of ranged attack can dispose of a brown mold easily; while pets are also capable of handling them, some early pets may have trouble dealing enough damage to outpace the mold's HP gain and passive damage.

Brown molds can provide an early source of cold resistance and poison resistance for a hero, in spite of the low odds.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a brown mold can be useful for giving resistances to a pet pony (e.g. as a Knight).

History

The brown mold first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, brown molds have a 9⁄10 chance of reviving from their corpses like other non-lichen fungi and molds.[8] A brown mold has an overall 7.4% chance of generating from a corpse that reaches 51 turns of age, is not acidic, and is not located within or on top of a square of water, ice or lava.[9][10][11][12]

Brown molds can be generated in fungus farms.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, brown molds have a roughly 1% chance to grow from old corpses similar to SLASH'EM, and can revive from their own corpses.

Brown mold corpses can only be eaten safely by a hero or monster with cold resistance, and will otherwise deal 2d12 damage when bitten into - their tins are still safe to consume.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses, though with much lower odds.

Brown mold corpses can be used to brew potions by dipping them in fruit juice, which eventually turns the juice into a potion of sleeping.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. A brown mold can grow up into a brown moldier, though this does not normally occur in gameplay.

Attempting to cook a brown mold corpse at a furnace will cause it to immediately revive.

notdNetHack

In notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, in addition to dNetHack details, brown molds can often be encountered in the Ice Caves adventure branch.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, tame monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a brown mold can be useful for giving resistances to a pet pony or other herbivore.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, red molds are slightly less likely to generate from old corpses due to the addition of some new fungi and molds. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. As in SpliceHack, a brown mold can grow up into a brown moldier, though this does not normally occur in gameplay.

Similar to xNetHack, brown mold corpses can be used to brew potions by dipping them in fruit juice - in Hack'EM, this eventually turns the juice into a potion of blood.

Monsters eating corpses functions as in EvilHack, allowing the hero to feed brown mold corpses to applicable pets so they can potentially gain intrinsics.

Encyclopedia entry

Mold, multicellular organism of the division Fungi, typified
by plant bodies composed of a network of cottony filaments.
The colors of molds are due to spores borne on the filaments.
Most molds are saprophytes. Some species (e.g., penicillium)
are used in making cheese and antibiotics.

[ The Concise Columbia Encyclopedia ]

A brown mold has a [[passive attack]] that can trigger when it is attacked in melee and not killed, dealing cold damage against attackers without [[cold resistance]] dependent on their level. This passive attack increases the mold's HP by half the damage inflicted{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2917|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case for cold passive against you}}{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2927|nethack=3.6.7|comment=cold passive healing against you}}{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1671|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case for cold passive against monsters}}{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1682|nethack=3.6.7|comment=cold passive healing against monsters}} - if enough HP is gained from this, the mold will undergo [[division]], halving its HP (rounded up) and creating a second mold with almost the same amount of HP.{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2933|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case against you calls split_mon function in [[potion.c]]}}{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1685|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case against monsters also calls split_mon function in [[potion.c]]}}{{refsrc|src/potion.c|2379|nethack=3.6.7|split_mon function - the "extra" hit point from halving an odd value is given to the original mold}} Brown molds possess [[poison resistance]] and cold resistance. [[Eating]] a brown mold [[corpse]] or [[tin]] has a 3% chance each of granting poison resistance or cold resistance. ==Generation== Randomly generated brown molds are always created hostile. ==Strategy== Brown molds are not threatening to a [[hero]] that has cold resistance, and even heroes without the property can avoid [[YASD]] against one by remaining attentive. Any form of [[ranged attack]] can dispose of a brown mold easily; while [[pet]]s are also capable of handling them, some early pets may have trouble dealing enough damage to outpace the mold's HP gain and passive damage. Brown molds can provide an early source of cold resistance and poison resistance for a hero, in spite of the low odds. {{upcoming|3.7.0|Monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a brown mold can be useful for giving resistances to a pet [[pony]] (e.g. as a [[Knight]]).}} ==History== The brown mold first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. ==Variants== ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], brown molds have a {{frac|9|10}} chance of [[reviving]] from their corpses like other non-[[lichen]] fungi and molds.{{refsrc|mkobj.c|764|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} A brown mold has an overall 7.4% chance of generating from a corpse that reaches 51 turns of age, is not [[acidic]], and is not located within or on top of a square of [[water]], [[ice]] or [[lava]].{{refsrc|mkobj.c|765|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|do.c|1685|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|mkobj.c|811|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|do.c|1680|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} Brown molds can be generated in [[fungus farm]]s. ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]], brown molds have a roughly 1% chance to grow from old corpses similar to SLASH'EM, and can revive from their own corpses. Brown mold corpses can only be eaten safely by a hero or monster with cold resistance, and will otherwise deal 2d12 damage when bitten into - their tins are still safe to consume. ===xNetHack=== In [[xNetHack]], brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from [[copper]] items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses, though with much lower odds. Brown mold corpses can be used to brew [[potion]]s by [[dipping]] them in [[fruit juice]], which eventually turns the juice into a [[potion of sleeping]]. ===SpliceHack=== In [[SpliceHack]], brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. A brown mold can [[grow up]] into a [[brown moldier]], though this does not normally occur in gameplay. Attempting to [[cook]] a brown mold corpse at a [[furnace]] will cause it to immediately revive. ===notdNetHack=== In [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], in addition to dNetHack details, brown molds can often be encountered in the [[Ice Caves]] [[adventure branch]]. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], tame monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a brown mold can be useful for giving resistances to a pet [[pony]] or other [[herbivore]]. ===SlashTHEM=== In [[SlashTHEM]], red molds are slightly less likely to generate from old corpses due to the addition of some new fungi and molds. All other SLASH'EM details apply. ===Hack'EM=== In [[Hack'EM]], brown molds and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. As in SpliceHack, a brown mold can grow up into a brown moldier, though this does not normally occur in gameplay. Similar to xNetHack, brown mold corpses can be used to brew potions by dipping them in fruit juice - in Hack'EM, this eventually turns the juice into a [[Potion of blood (SLASH'EM)|potion of blood]]. Monsters eating corpses functions as in EvilHack, allowing the hero to feed brown mold corpses to applicable pets so they can potentially gain intrinsics. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia|Mold, multicellular organism of the division Fungi, typified by plant bodies composed of a network of cottony filaments. The colors of molds are due to spores borne on the filaments. Most molds are saprophytes. Some species (e.g., penicillium) are used in making cheese and antibiotics. |[ The Concise Columbia Encyclopedia ] }} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Monsters]]
